Source Origin: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)
Notes: The major Dushanbe-Anzob-Istarafshan road was severely affected at several points and key bridges were destroyed or damaged. 400,000 people affected in terms of loss of access to safe water, especially in Dushanbe, where 60% of the population lost drinking water supply due to pollution from the Varzob River. The Varzob valley floods severely damaged infrastructure including roads and bridges connecting the capital and key regions.

Source Origin: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC)

Source Origin: United Nations Country Team (UNCT)
No. Infrastucture Destroyed/Damaged: One secondary school, six shops, two pedestrian bridges and two motorway bridges, one petrol station, 6 kilometres of high-voltage power line (35 kWt), 2 kilometres of power line (10 kWt), 2 kilometres of regional level motor road, five parking lots, six cars and 1,300 metres of irrigation channels as well as 3,000 various trees. Motor roads, power lines, agricultural lands, buildings and similar facilities, and other socio-economic infrastructure were destroyed. Even a section of the strategic Khorog-Murgab road of 3.5 kilometre length was completely destroyed.

Source Origin: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC)
No. Infrastucture Destroyed/Damaged: Approximately 1.5 km of local roads, 3.5 km of irrigation channels, and 1.5 km of the drinking water system were damaged. In addition, one secondary school building was impacted
Notes: Overall, the infrastructure damage affected a broader population of approximately 3,842 people in Amondara village.

Source Origin: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC)

The main road connecting Kurgoncha village of Jabbor Rasulov district with the district centre town was blocked. A pedestrian bridge constructed under the RCST “Transborder” programme in that village was destroyed.

Mudflows triggered by heavy rains and strong winds affected 11 districts of the Sughd Province in north-western Tajikistan, killing 3 people and severely damaging approximately 170 houses along with public infrastructure and arable land.

Source Origin: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC)

No. Infrastucture Destroyed/Damaged: 1 school destroyed, 7 km of paved roads damaged, 6 bridges damaged, electricity cables and water pipes ruined, 340 hectares of planted fields affected.
Notes: As a result of heavy rains and strong winds on 7-8 June 2015 in the northern part of Tajikistan, floods and mudslides hit the population of three districts of Sughd province. According to the feedback and reports received from the Red Crescent Society of Tajikistan`s (RCST) response teams and Governmental Emergency Committee sources, up to 615 families (3,075 people) were directly affected: in 572 families in J. Rasulov district, one family in Isfara district and 42 families in Ainy district

Source Origin: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)
No. Infrastucture Destroyed/Damaged: Farmlands, over 3.000 ha of cotton plantations and infrastructure such as roads and bridges were damaged. According to the Ministry of Emergency Situations the largest landslide buried around 100 metres of the water supply pipeline in the village of Qadi Ob in the Rogun District.
Notes: During the last week of April and the first days of May 2006 heavy rain, hail and wind caused several mudslides and floods in southern Tajikistan. Farmlands, over 3.000 ha of cotton plantations and infrastructure such as roads and bridges were damaged in a number of districts of Khatlon Oblast (Muminobod, Shurobod, Danghara, Temurmalik, Jomi and Yovon). One casualty is reported in Khorasan District of Khatlon Oblast.

Source Origin: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC)
No. Infrastucture Destroyed/Damaged: The water pipeline system has been destroyed due to the floods. In Vashny (the town centre), the water, electricity and communication system is still functioning. Several bridges and many kilometres of roads have been destroyed

Notes: 10 people are missing and 23 injured
